_header: As the Pilgrims forth did ride
_description: Prologue to ‘The Ploughman’s Tale’ (6603) inserted into in one version of Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales (6414) — two rhyme royal stanzas

OxfChrCh152.First Lines:
As the Pylgrymys fforth ded rydeOwr host be gan to loke
                    A boute…
OxfChrCh152.Last Lines:
…And heuene blysse had to hys medeHoo seruyth Owr lady the
                    better shalle spede
OxfChrCh152.Note:
An incipit for the tale is copied at the foot of f.
                        248v, and then crossed out, with the ‘Prologue’
                    continuing on f. 229. The ‘Tale’ follows on f. 229 (6603).
OxfChrCh152.Attributed Title:
The prologe of the Ploughman (f. 228v); Here be gynnyth the
                        tale (f. 148v, foot)
OxfChrCh152.Editions:
Bowers,  John M.,
                        ed.  
             The Canterbury Tales:
                    Fifteenth-Century Continuations and Additions.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Medieval Institute Publications, 1992.
